CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (non-exhaustion);Violation of Art. 5-4;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . On DATE ORG charged the applicant with assault causing bodily harm on the ground that he had hit a neighbour . On DATE ORG Okresný súd ) issued a penal order by which the applicant was conditionally sentenced to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . Upon the applicant ’s complaint ORG quashed the penal order and scheduled a hearing in the case .

CARDINAL . On DATE a hearing was held before ORG . It was adjourned because of the applicant ’s misbehaviour . A further hearing was held on DATE . As the applicant did not behave properly , the judge ordered him to be removed from the court building . The hearing was held in his absence . The applicant was convicted of assault causing bodily harm . A conditional CARDINAL months’ prison sentence was imposed . On DATE ORG ( PERSON súd ) dismissed the applicant ’s appeal .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG úrad vyšetrovania ) charged the applicant with contempt of court , allegedly committed on DATE during the first hearing before ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered a psychiatric examination of the applicant in the context of the criminal proceedings . The applicant submitted a certificate from a NORP doctor dated DATE and refused to be examined as an out - patient .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the applicant sought redress from ORG ( Ústavný súd ) alleging that the criminal proceedings were unfair , including the order for his psychiatric examination . By letter of ORG of DATE he was informed that ORG is not superior to the police , prosecutor or ordinary courts and that it is not an appellate body in the ordinary court system . He was further informed that ORG has no jurisdiction to change or quash the decisions of ordinary courts or to interfere with their jurisdiction and that judicial decisions can be remedied by the means and according to the procedures prescribed by law .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , ORG had ordered that the applicant be detained for observation in a mental hospital pursuant to LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . The applicant received the decision on DATE , and on DATE he challenged it .
CARDINAL . On DATE the mental hospital summoned the applicant to be admitted on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was handcuffed and escorted by the police to the mental hospital . No warrant was presented . The applicant stayed in the mental hospital until DATE . From DATE he was granted leave .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s wife complained to ORG that on DATE the applicant had been confined in the mental hospital although he had appealed against ORG order of DATE . She claimed that the applicant ’s detention in the mental hospital was unlawful .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s complaint against ORG order of DATE . The decision was notified to ORG on DATE . It was not served on the applicant .
CARDINAL . By letter of CARDINAL DATE , served on the applicant ’s wife on DATE , ORG informed her that her complaint had been referred , for reasons of competence , to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecution for contempt of court was stayed in the light of the experts’ conclusion that the applicant suffered from a permanent personality disorder which had prevented him from controlling his behaviour during the hearing before ORG of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the applicant ’s wife that her complaint of CARDINAL DATE had been sent , for reasons of competence , to ORG . The applicant and his wife received no further information in this respect .
CARDINAL . By virtue of LAW ) , ORG may commence proceedings upon a petition ( podnet ) presented by an individual or a corporation claiming that their rights have been violated .

CARDINAL . DATE ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) provide that personal liberty of every individual shall be guaranteed and no one shall be prosecuted or deprived of liberty unless for reasons and by methods set by law . According to LAW ( CARDINAL ) , a person may be committed to or held in a health - care institution without his or her consent only in cases specified by law . Such cases shall be reported to a court within TIME and the court shall decide within DATE . According to LAW , “ a psychological examination of a person charged with an offence is permissible only upon a written court order ” .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) provides for the appointment , upon a written order by the court , of CARDINAL psychiatric experts when there is a need to examine the mental health of the accused . Pursuant to LAW ( CARDINAL ) , if the mental health of the accused can not be examined in any other way , the court can order detention for observation in an institution . The order can be challenged by a complaint which has suspensive effect .

CARDINAL . According to Section CARDINAL , the accused has a right , at any time in the course of the investigation , to request the rectification of defects in the investigator ’s procedure . Such a request , to which no statute of limitation applies , must be submitted immediately to the public prosecutor who is required to deal with it without delay , and to inform the accused about the finding of the review .

CARDINAL . In the judgment No . I ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ORG , sitting in a chamber of CARDINAL judges , ordered the release of a patient confined in a mental establishment without his consent . In this case , the patient had been detained for DATE without any authorisation by a competent ordinary court . He alleged a violation of LAW ) of the LAW and ORG considered the matter in the light of LAW . This judgment was not included in LAW ( ORG nálezov a uznesení ) published by ORG and comprising decisions which the plenary session of ORG considers important from the legal point of view . The judgment has been neither confirmed nor developed subsequently .

CARDINAL . In its subsequent practice ORG has consistently held that it is not an appellate body in the ordinary court system and that it has no jurisdiction to interfere with proceedings before ordinary courts or to quash their decisions .
